SubElements.label: T1
SubElements.description: FCC Rules, descriptions, and definitions for the Amateur Radio Service, operator and station license responsibilities

subTopics.label: T1A
subTopics.description: Amateur Radio Service: purpose and permissible use of the Amateur Radio Service, operator/primary station license grant; Meanings of basic terms used in FCC rules; Interference; RACES rules; Phonetics; Frequency Coordinator

questions.label: T1A01
questions.text: Which of the following is a purpose of the Amateur Radio Service as stated in the FCC rules and regulations?
distractors: Providing personal radio communications for as many citizens as possible
Providing communications for international non-profit organizations
All of these choices are correct
questions.answer: Advancing skills in the technical and communication phases of the radio art

questions.label: T1A02
questions.text: Which agency regulates and enforces the rules for the Amateur Radio Service in the United States?
distractors: All of these choices are correct

questions.label: T1A03
questions.text: What are the FCC rules regarding the use of a phonetic alphabet for station identification in the Amateur Radio Service?
distractors: It is required when transmitting emergency messages
It is required when in contact with foreign stations

questions.label: T1A04
questions.text: How many operator/primary station license grants may be held by any one person?
distractors: One for each band on which the person plans to operate
One for each permanent station location from which the person plans to operate

questions.label: T1A05
questions.text: What is proof of possession of an FCC-issued operator/primary license grant?
distractors: A printed operator/primary station license issued by the FCC must be displayed at the transmitter site
The control operator must have an operator/primary station license in his or her possession when in control of a transmitter
All of these choices are correct
questions.answer: The control operator's operator/primary station license must appear in the FCC ULS consolidated licensee database

questions.label: T1A06
questions.text: What is the FCC Part 97 definition of a beacon?
distractors: A government transmitter marking the amateur radio band edges
A bulletin sent by the FCC to announce a national emergency
A continuous transmission of weather information authorized in the amateur bands by the National Weather Service
questions.answer: An amateur station transmitting communications for the purposes of observing propagation or related experimental activities

questions.label: T1A07
questions.text: What is the FCC Part 97 definition of a space station?
distractors: A manned satellite orbiting the earth
An amateur station using amateur radio satellites for relay of signals
questions.answer: An amateur station located more than 50 km above the Earth's surface

questions.label: T1A08
questions.text: Which of the following entities recommends transmit/receive channels and other parameters for auxiliary and repeater stations?
distractors: Frequency Spectrum Manager appointed by the FCC
questions.answer: Volunteer Frequency Coordinator recognized by local amateurs

questions.label: T1A09
questions.text: Who selects a Frequency Coordinator?
distractors: The FCC Office of Spectrum Management and Coordination Policy
The local chapter of the Office of National Council of Independent Frequency Coordinators
questions.answer: Amateur operators in a local or regional area whose stations are eligible to be repeater or auxiliary stations

questions.label: T1A10
questions.text: Which of the following describes the Radio Amateur Civil Emergency Service (RACES)?
distractors: A radio service using amateur frequencies for emergency management or civil defense communications
A radio service using amateur stations for emergency management or civil defense communications
An emergency service using amateur operators certified by a civil defense organization as being enrolled in that organization
questions.answer: All of these choices are correct

questions.label: T1A11
questions.text: When is willful interference to other amateur radio stations permitted?
distractors: To stop another amateur station which is breaking the FCC rules
At any time, stations in the Amateur Radio Service are not protected from willful interference

subTopics.label: T1B
subTopics.description: Authorized frequencies: frequency allocations; ITU; emission modes; restricted sub-bands; spectrum sharing; transmissions near band edges; contacting the International Space Station; power output

questions.label: T1B01
questions.text: What is the International Telecommunications Union (ITU)?
distractors: An agency of the United States Department of Telecommunications Management
questions.answer: A United Nations agency for information and communication technology issues

questions.label: T1B02
questions.text: Which amateur radio stations may make contact with an amateur radio station on the International Space Station (ISS) using 2 meter and 70 cm band frequencies?
distractors: Only members of amateur radio clubs at NASA facilities
Only the astronaut's family members who are hams
Contacts with the ISS are not permitted on amateur radio frequencies
questions.answer: Any amateur holding a Technician or higher-class license

questions.label: T1B03
questions.text: Which frequency is within the 6 meter amateur band?

questions.label: T1B04
questions.text: Which amateur band are you using when your station is transmitting on 146.52 MHz?

questions.label: T1B05
questions.text: What is the limitation for emissions on the frequencies between 219 and 220 MHz?
questions.answer: Fixed digital message forwarding systems only

questions.label: T1B06
questions.text: On which HF bands does a Technician class operator have phone privileges?
distractors: 80 meter, 40 meter, 15 meter and 10 meter bands

questions.label: T1B07
questions.text: Which of the following VHF/UHF frequency ranges are limited to CW only?
distractors: 219 MHz to 220 MHz and 420.0 MHz to 420.1 MHz
All of these choices are correct
questions.answer: 50.0 MHz to 50.1 MHz and 144.0 MHz to 144.1 MHz

questions.label: T1B08
questions.text: Which of the following is a result of the fact that the Amateur Radio Service is secondary in all or portions of some amateur bands (such as portions of the 70 cm band)?
distractors: U.S. amateurs must give foreign amateur stations priority in those portions
International communications are not permitted in those portions
Digital transmissions are not permitted in those portions
questions.answer: U.S. amateurs may find non-amateur stations in those portions, and must avoid interfering with them

questions.label: T1B09
questions.text: Why should you not set your transmit frequency to be exactly at the edge of an amateur band or sub-band?
distractors: To allow for calibration error in the transmitter frequency display
So that modulation sidebands do not extend beyond the band edge
To allow for transmitter frequency drift
questions.answer: All of these choices are correct

questions.label: T1B10
questions.text: Which of the following HF bands have frequencies available to the Technician class operator for RTTY and data transmissions?
distractors: 10 meter, 12 meter, 17 meter, and 40 meter bands
10 meter, 15 meter, 40 meter, and 80 meter bands

questions.label: T1B11
questions.text: What is the maximum peak envelope power output for Technician class operators using their assigned portions of the HF bands?

questions.label: T1B12
questions.text: Except for some specific restrictions, what is the maximum peak envelope power output for Technician class operators using frequencies above 30 MHz?

subTopics.label: T1C
subTopics.description: Operator licensing: operator classes; sequential and vanity call sign systems; international communications; reciprocal operation; places where the Amateur Radio Service is regulated by the FCC; name and address on FCC license database; license term; renewal; grace period

questions.label: T1C01
questions.text: For which license classes are new licenses currently available from the FCC?

questions.label: T1C02
questions.text: Who may select a desired call sign under the vanity call sign rules?
distractors: Only a licensed amateur with a General or Amateur Extra class license
Only a licensed amateur with an Amateur Extra class license
Only a licensed amateur who has been licensed continuously for more than 10 years

questions.label: T1C03
questions.text: What types of international communications is an FCC-licensed amateur radio station permitted to make?
distractors: Communications incidental to conducting business or remarks of a personal nature
Only communications incidental to contest exchanges, all other communications are prohibited
Any communications that would be permitted by an international broadcast station
questions.answer: Communications incidental to the purposes of the Amateur Radio Service and remarks of a personal character

questions.label: T1C04
questions.text: When are you allowed to operate your amateur station in a foreign country?
distractors: When there is a mutual agreement allowing third party communications
When authorization permits amateur communications in a foreign language
When you are communicating with non-licensed individuals in another country
questions.answer: When the foreign country authorizes it

questions.label: T1C05
questions.text: Which of the following is a valid call sign for a Technician class amateur radio station?
distractors: All of these choices are correct

questions.label: T1C06
questions.text: From which of the following locations may an FCC-licensed amateur station transmit?
distractors: From within any country that belongs to the International Telecommunications Union
From within any country that is a member of the United Nations
From anywhere within International Telecommunications Union (ITU) Regions 2 and 3
questions.answer: From any vessel or craft located in international waters and documented or registered in the United States

questions.label: T1C07
questions.text: What may result when correspondence from the FCC is returned as undeliverable because the grantee failed to provide and maintain a correct mailing address with the FCC?
distractors: Require the licensee to be re-examined
A reduction of one rank in operator class
questions.answer: Revocation of the station license or suspension of the operator license

questions.label: T1C08
questions.text: What is the normal term for an FCC-issued primary station/operator amateur radio license grant?

questions.label: T1C09
questions.text: What is the grace period following the expiration of an amateur license within which the license may be renewed?

questions.label: T1C10
questions.text: How soon after passing the examination for your first amateur radio license may you operate a transmitter on an Amateur Radio Service frequency?
distractors: You must wait until you receive your license in the mail from the FCC
questions.answer: As soon as your operator/station license grant appears in the FCC’s license database

questions.label: T1C11
questions.text: If your license has expired and is still within the allowable grace period, may you continue to operate a transmitter on Amateur Radio Service frequencies?
distractors: Yes, but only if you identify using the suffix GP
Yes, but only during authorized nets
Yes, for up to two years
questions.answer: No, transmitting is not allowed until the FCC license database shows that the license has been renewed

subTopics.label: T1D
subTopics.description: Authorized and prohibited transmission: communications with other countries; music; exchange of information with other services; indecent language; compensation for use of station; retransmission of other amateur signals; codes and ciphers; sale of equipment; unidentified transmissions; one-way transmission

questions.label: T1D01
questions.text: With which countries are FCC-licensed amateur radio stations prohibited from exchanging communications?
distractors: Any country whose administration has notified the American Radio Relay League (ARRL) that it objects to such communications
Any country engaged in hostilities with another country
Any country in violation of the War Powers Act of 1934
questions.answer: Any country whose administration has notified the International Telecommunications Union (ITU) that it objects to such communications

questions.label: T1D02
questions.text: Under which of the following circumstances may an amateur radio station make one-way transmissions?
distractors: At any time, as long as no music is transmitted
At any time, as long as the material being transmitted did not originate from a commercial broadcast station
questions.answer: When transmitting code practice, information bulletins, or transmissions necessary to provide emergency communications

questions.label: T1D03
questions.text: When is it permissible to transmit messages encoded to hide their meaning?
distractors: Only when frequencies above 1280 MHz are used
questions.answer: Only when transmitting control commands to space stations or radio control craft

questions.label: T1D04
questions.text: Under what conditions is an amateur station authorized to transmit music using a phone emission?
distractors: When the music produces no spurious emissions
When the purpose is to interfere with an illegal transmission
When the music is transmitted above 1280 MHz
questions.answer: When incidental to an authorized retransmission of manned spacecraft communications

questions.label: T1D05
questions.text: When may amateur radio operators use their stations to notify other amateurs of the availability of equipment for sale or trade?
distractors: When the asking price is $100.00 or less
When the asking price is less than its appraised value
When the equipment is not the personal property of either the station licensee or the control operator or their close relatives
questions.answer: When the equipment is normally used in an amateur station and such activity is not conducted on a regular basis

questions.label: T1D06
questions.text: What, if any, are the restrictions concerning transmission of language that may be considered indecent or obscene?
distractors: The FCC maintains a list of words that are not permitted to be used on amateur frequencies
The ITU maintains a list of words that are not permitted to be used on amateur frequencies

questions.label: T1D07
questions.text: What types of amateur stations can automatically retransmit the signals of other amateur stations?

questions.label: T1D08
questions.text: In which of the following circumstances may the control operator of an amateur station receive compensation for operating that station?
distractors: When the communication is related to the sale of amateur equipment by the control operator's employer
When the communication is made to obtain emergency information for a local broadcast station
All of these choices are correct
questions.answer: When the communication is incidental to classroom instruction at an educational institution

questions.label: T1D09
questions.text: Under which of the following circumstances are amateur stations authorized to transmit signals related to broadcasting, program production, or news gathering, assuming no other means is available?
distractors: Only when broadcasting communications to or from the space shuttle
Only where noncommercial programming is gathered and supplied exclusively to the National Public Radio network
Only when using amateur repeaters linked to the internet
questions.answer: Only where such communications directly relate to the immediate safety of human life or protection of property

questions.label: T1D10
questions.text: What is the meaning of the term broadcasting in the FCC rules for the Amateur Radio Service?
distractors: Transmission of messages directed only to amateur operators
questions.answer: Transmissions intended for reception by the general public

questions.label: T1D11
questions.text: When may an amateur station transmit without on-the-air identification?
distractors: When the transmissions are of a brief nature to make station adjustments
When the transmitted power level is below 1 watt
questions.answer: When transmitting signals to control model craft

subTopics.label: T1E
subTopics.description: Control operator and control types: control operator required; eligibility; designation of control operator; privileges and duties; control point; local, automatic and remote control; location of control operator

questions.label: T1E01
questions.text: When is an amateur station permitted to transmit without a control operator?
distractors: When using automatic control, such as in the case of a repeater
When the station licensee is away and another licensed amateur is using the station
When the transmitting station is an auxiliary station

questions.label: T1E02
questions.text: Who may be the control operator of a station communicating through an amateur satellite or space station?
distractors: Only an Amateur Extra Class operator
A General class or higher licensee who has a satellite operator certification
Only an Amateur Extra Class operator who is also an AMSAT member
questions.answer: Any amateur whose license privileges allow them to transmit on the satellite uplink frequency

questions.label: T1E03
questions.text: Who must designate the station control operator?

questions.label: T1E04
questions.text: What determines the transmitting privileges of an amateur station?
distractors: The frequency authorized by the frequency coordinator
The frequencies printed on the license grant
The highest class of operator license held by anyone on the premises
questions.answer: The class of operator license held by the control operator

questions.label: T1E05
questions.text: What is an amateur station control point?
distractors: The location of the station’s transmitting antenna
The location of the station transmitting apparatus
The mailing address of the station licensee
questions.answer: The location at which the control operator function is performed

questions.label: T1E06
questions.text: When, under normal circumstances, may a Technician class licensee be the control operator of a station operating in an exclusive Amateur Extra class operator segment of the amateur bands?
distractors: When operating a special event station
As part of a multi-operator contest team
When using a club station whose trustee is an Amateur Extra class operator licensee

questions.label: T1E07
questions.text: When the control operator is not the station licensee, who is responsible for the proper operation of the station?
distractors: All licensed amateurs who are present at the operation
questions.answer: The control operator and the station licensee are equally responsible

questions.label: T1E08
questions.text: Which of the following is an example of automatic control?
distractors: Controlling the station over the internet
Using a computer or other device to send CW automatically
Using a computer or other device to identify automatically

questions.label: T1E09
questions.text: Which of the following is true of remote control operation?
distractors: The control operator must be at the control point
A control operator is required at all times
The control operator indirectly manipulates the controls
questions.answer: All of these choices are correct

questions.label: T1E10
questions.text: Which of the following is an example of remote control as defined in Part 97?
distractors: Controlling a model aircraft, boat, or car by amateur radio
All of these choices are correct
questions.answer: Operating the station over the internet

questions.label: T1E11
questions.text: Who does the FCC presume to be the control operator of an amateur station, unless documentation to the contrary is in the station records?
distractors: The person operating the station equipment

subTopics.label: T1F
subTopics.description: Station identification; repeaters; third-party communications; club stations; FCC inspection

questions.label: T1F01
questions.text: When must the station licensee make the station and its records available for FCC inspection?
distractors: At any time ten days after notification by the FCC of such an inspection
Only after failing to comply with an FCC notice of violation
Only when presented with a valid warrant by an FCC official or government agent
questions.answer: At any time upon request by an FCC representative

questions.label: T1F02
questions.text: When using tactical identifiers such as “Race Headquarters” during a community service net operation, how often must your station transmit the station’s FCC-assigned call sign?
distractors: Never, the tactical call is sufficient
At the end of every transmission
questions.answer: At the end of each communication and every ten minutes during a communication

questions.label: T1F03
questions.text: When is an amateur station required to transmit its assigned call sign?
distractors: At the beginning of each contact, and every 10 minutes thereafter
At least once during each transmission
At least every 15 minutes during and at the end of a communication
questions.answer: At least every 10 minutes during and at the end of a communication

questions.label: T1F04
questions.text: Which of the following is an acceptable language to use for station identification when operating in a phone sub-band?
distractors: Any language recognized by the United Nations
Any language recognized by the ITU

questions.label: T1F05
questions.text: What method of call sign identification is required for a station transmitting phone signals?
distractors: Send the call sign followed by the indicator RPT
Send the call sign followed by the indicator R
Send the call sign using only a phone emission
questions.answer: Send the call sign using a CW or phone emission

questions.label: T1F06
questions.text: Which of the following formats of a self-assigned indicator is acceptable when identifying using a phone transmission?
questions.answer: All of these choices are correct

questions.label: T1F07
questions.text: Which of the following restrictions apply when a non-licensed person is allowed to speak to a foreign station using a station under the control of a Technician class control operator?
distractors: The person must be a U.S. citizen
The licensed control operator must do the station identification
All of these choices are correct
questions.answer: The foreign station must be one with which the U.S. has a third-party agreement

questions.label: T1F08
questions.text: What is meant by the term Third Party Communications?
distractors: Amateur radio communications where three stations are in communications with one another
Operation when the transmitting equipment is licensed to a person other than the control operator
Temporary authorization for an unlicensed person to transmit on the amateur bands for technical experiments
questions.answer: A message from a control operator to another amateur station control operator on behalf of another person

questions.label: T1F09
questions.text: What type of amateur station simultaneously retransmits the signal of another amateur station on a different channel or channels?

questions.label: T1F10
questions.text: Who is accountable should a repeater inadvertently retransmit communications that violate the FCC rules?
distractors: The control operator of the repeater
Both the originating station and the repeater owner
questions.answer: The control operator of the originating station

questions.label: T1F11
questions.text: Which of the following is a requirement for the issuance of a club station license grant?
distractors: The trustee must have an Amateur Extra class operator license grant
The club must be registered with the American Radio Relay League
All of these choices are correct
questions.answer: The club must have at least four members

subTopics.label: T2A
subTopics.description: Station operation: choosing an operating frequency; calling another station; test transmissions; procedural signs; use of minimum power; choosing an operating frequency; band plans; calling frequencies; repeater offsets

questions.label: T2A01
questions.text: Which of the following is a common repeater frequency offset in the 2 meter band?

questions.label: T2A02
questions.text: What is the national calling frequency for FM simplex operations in the 2 meter band?

questions.label: T2A03
questions.text: What is a common repeater frequency offset in the 70 cm band?

questions.label: T2A04
questions.text: What is an appropriate way to call another station on a repeater if you know the other station's call sign?
distractors: Say "break, break," then say the station's call sign
Say "CQ" three times, then the other station's call sign
Wait for the station to call CQ, then answer it
questions.answer: Say the station's call sign, then identify with your call sign

questions.label: T2A05
questions.text: How should you respond to a station calling CQ?
distractors: Transmit "CQ" followed by the other station’s call sign
Transmit your call sign followed by the other station’s call sign
Transmit a signal report followed by your call sign
questions.answer: Transmit the other station’s call sign followed by your call sign

questions.label: T2A06
questions.text: Which of the following is required when making on-the-air test transmissions?
distractors: Conduct tests only between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m. local time
Notify the FCC of the transmissions
All of these choices are correct

questions.label: T2A07
questions.text: What is meant by "repeater offset?"
distractors: The repeater has a time delay to prevent interference
The repeater station identification is done on a separate frequency
The number of simultaneous transmit frequencies used by a repeater
questions.answer: The difference between a repeater’s transmit frequency and its receive frequency

questions.label: T2A08
questions.text: What is the meaning of the procedural signal “CQ”?
distractors: A new antenna is being tested (no station should answer)
Only the called station should transmit

questions.label: T2A09
questions.text: What brief statement indicates that you are listening on a repeater and looking for a contact?
distractors: The words “Hello test” followed by your call sign
The repeater call sign followed by your call sign
The letters “QSY” followed by your call sign

questions.label: T2A10
questions.text: What is a band plan, beyond the privileges established by the FCC?
distractors: A mandated list of operating schedules
A list of scheduled net frequencies
A plan devised by a club to indicate frequency band usage
questions.answer: A voluntary guideline for using different modes or activities within an amateur band

questions.label: T2A11
questions.text: What term describes an amateur station that is transmitting and receiving on the same frequency?

questions.label: T2A12
questions.text: Which of the following is a guideline when choosing an operating frequency for calling CQ?
distractors: Listen first to be sure that no one else is using the frequency
Ask if the frequency is in use
Make sure you are in your assigned band
questions.answer: All of these choices are correct

subTopics.label: T2B
subTopics.description: VHF/UHF operating practices: SSB phone; FM repeater; simplex; splits and shifts; CTCSS; DTMF; tone squelch; carrier squelch; phonetics; operational problem resolution; Q signals

questions.label: T2B01
questions.text: What is the most common use of the “reverse split” function of a VHF/UHF transceiver?
distractors: Listen on a repeater’s output frequency
questions.answer: Listen on a repeater’s input frequency

questions.label: T2B02
questions.text: What term describes the use of a sub-audible tone transmitted along with normal voice audio to open the squelch of a receiver?

questions.label: T2B03
questions.text: If a station is not strong enough to keep a repeater’s receiver squelch open, which of the following might allow you to receive the station’s signal?
distractors: Open the squelch on your radio
Listen on the repeater output frequency
questions.answer: Listen on the repeater input frequency

questions.label: T2B04
questions.text: Which of the following could be the reason you are unable to access a repeater whose output you can hear?
distractors: The repeater may require a proper CTCSS tone from your transceiver
The repeater may require a proper DCS tone from your transceiver
questions.answer: All of these choices are correct

questions.label: T2B05
questions.text: What might be the problem if a repeater user says your transmissions are breaking up on voice peaks?
distractors: Your transmit power is too high

questions.label: T2B06
questions.text: What type of tones are used to control repeaters linked by the Internet Relay Linking Project (IRLP) protocol?

questions.label: T2B07
questions.text: How can you join a digital repeater’s “talk group”?
distractors: Register your radio with the local FCC office
Sign your call after the courtesy tone
questions.answer: Program your radio with the group’s ID or code

questions.label: T2B08
questions.text: Which of the following applies when two stations transmitting on the same frequency interfere with each other?
distractors: Whoever has the strongest signal has priority on the frequency
Whoever has been on the frequency the longest has priority on the frequency
The station that has the weakest signal has priority on the frequency
questions.answer: Common courtesy should prevail, but no one has absolute right to an amateur frequency

questions.label: T2B09
questions.text: What is a “talk group” on a DMR digital repeater?
distractors: A group of operators sharing common interests
A protocol that increases the signal-to-noise ratio when multiple repeaters are linked together
A net that meets at a particular time
questions.answer: A way for groups of users to share a channel at different times without being heard by other users on the channel

questions.label: T2B10
questions.text: Which Q signal indicates that you are receiving interference from other stations?

questions.label: T2B11
questions.text: Which Q signal indicates that you are changing frequency?

questions.label: T2B12
questions.text: Why are simplex channels designated in the VHF/UHF band plans?
distractors: So that stations with simple transmitters can access the repeater without automated offset
questions.answer: So that stations within mutual communications range can communicate without tying up a repeater

questions.label: T2B13
questions.text: Where may SSB phone be used in amateur bands above 50 MHz?
distractors: Only in sub-bands allocated to General class or higher licensees
On any band as long as power is limited to 25 watts
questions.answer: In at least some portion of all these bands

questions.label: T2B14
questions.text: Which of the following describes a linked repeater network?
distractors: A repeater with more than one receiver
Multiple repeaters with the same owner
A system of repeaters linked by APRS
questions.answer: A network of repeaters where signals received by one repeater are repeated by all the repeaters

subTopics.label: T2C
subTopics.description: Public service: emergency and non-emergency operations; applicability of FCC rules; RACES and ARES; net and traffic procedures; operating restrictions during emergencies

questions.label: T2C01
questions.text: When do the FCC rules NOT apply to the operation of an amateur station?
distractors: When operating under special FEMA rules
When operating under special ARES rules

questions.label: T2C02
questions.text: What is meant by the term "NCS" used in net operation?

questions.label: T2C03
questions.text: What should be done when using voice modes to ensure that voice messages containing unusual words are received correctly?
distractors: Send the words by voice and Morse code
Speak very loudly into the microphone
All of these choices are correct
questions.answer: Spell the words using a standard phonetic alphabet

questions.label: T2C04
questions.text: What do RACES and ARES have in common?
distractors: They represent the two largest ham clubs in the United States
Both organizations broadcast road and weather information
Neither may handle emergency traffic supporting public service agencies
questions.answer: Both organizations may provide communications during emergencies

questions.label: T2C05
questions.text: What does the term “traffic” refer to in net operation?
distractors: The number of stations checking in and out of a net
Operation by mobile or portable stations
Requests to activate the net by a served agency
questions.answer: Formal messages exchanged by net stations

questions.label: T2C06
questions.text: Which of the following is an accepted practice to get the immediate attention of a net control station when reporting an emergency?
distractors: Repeat "SOS" three times followed by the call sign of the reporting station
Press the push-to-talk button three times
Play a pre-recorded emergency alert tone followed by your call sign
questions.answer: Begin your transmission by saying "Priority" or "Emergency" followed by your call sign

questions.label: T2C07
questions.text: Which of the following is an accepted practice for an amateur operator who has checked into a net?
distractors: Provided that the frequency is quiet, announce the station call sign and location every 5 minutes
Move 5 kHz away from the net's frequency and use high power to ask other hams to keep clear of the net frequency
All of these choices are correct
questions.answer: Remain on frequency without transmitting until asked to do so by the net control station

questions.label: T2C08
questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of good traffic handling?
distractors: Making decisions as to whether messages are worthy of relay or delivery
Ensuring that any newsworthy messages are relayed to the news media
All of these choices are correct

questions.label: T2C09
questions.text: Are amateur station control operators ever permitted to operate outside the frequency privileges of their license class?
distractors: Yes, but only when part of a FEMA emergency plan
Yes, but only when part of a RACES emergency plan
questions.answer: Yes, but only if necessary in situations involving the immediate safety of human life or protection of property

questions.label: T2C10
questions.text: What information is contained in the preamble of a formal traffic message?
distractors: The email address of the originating station
The address of the intended recipient
The telephone number of the addressee
questions.answer: The information needed to track the message

questions.label: T2C11
questions.text: What is meant by the term “check,” in reference to a formal traffic message?
distractors: The value of a money order attached to the message
A list of stations that have relayed the message
A box on the message form that indicates that the message was received and/or relayed
questions.answer: The number of words or word equivalents in the text portion of the message

questions.label: T2C12
questions.text: What is the Amateur Radio Emergency Service (ARES)?
distractors: Licensed amateurs who are members of the military and who voluntarily agreed to provide message handling services in the case of an emergency
A training program that provides licensing courses for those interested in obtaining an amateur license to use during emergencies
A training program that certifies amateur operators for membership in the Radio Amateur Civil Emergency Service
questions.answer: Licensed amateurs who have voluntarily registered their qualifications and equipment for communications duty in the public service

SubElements.label: T3
SubElements.description: Radio wave characteristics: properties of radio waves; propagation modes

subTopics.label: T3A
subTopics.description: Radio wave characteristics: how a radio signal travels; fading; multipath; polarization; wavelength vs absorption; antenna orientation

questions.label: T3A01
questions.text: What should you do if another operator reports that your station’s 2 meter signals were strong just a moment ago, but now they are weak or distorted?
distractors: Change the batteries in your radio to a different type
Ask the other operator to adjust his squelch control
questions.answer: Try moving a few feet or changing the direction of your antenna if possible, as reflections may be causing multi-path distortion

questions.label: T3A02
questions.text: Why might the range of VHF and UHF signals be greater in the winter?

questions.label: T3A03
questions.text: What antenna polarization is normally used for long-distance weak-signal CW and SSB contacts using the VHF and UHF bands?

questions.label: T3A04
questions.text: What can happen if the antennas at opposite ends of a VHF or UHF line of sight radio link are not using the same polarization?
distractors: The modulation sidebands might become inverted
Signals have an echo effect on voices

questions.label: T3A05
questions.text: When using a directional antenna, how might your station be able to access a distant repeater if buildings or obstructions are blocking the direct line of sight path?
distractors: Change from vertical to horizontal polarization
questions.answer: Try to find a path that reflects signals to the repeater

questions.label: T3A06
questions.text: What term is commonly used to describe the rapid fluttering sound sometimes heard from mobile stations that are moving while transmitting?

questions.label: T3A07
questions.text: What type of wave carries radio signals between transmitting and receiving stations?

questions.label: T3A08
questions.text: Which of the following is a likely cause of irregular fading of signals received by ionospheric reflection?
distractors: Frequency shift due to Faraday rotation
questions.answer: Random combining of signals arriving via different paths

questions.label: T3A09
questions.text: Which of the following results from the fact that skip signals refracted from the ionosphere are elliptically polarized?
distractors: Both the transmitting and receiving antennas must be of the same polarization
questions.answer: Either vertically or horizontally polarized antennas may be used for transmission or reception

questions.label: T3A10
questions.text: What may occur if data signals arrive via multiple paths?
distractors: Transmission rates can be increased by a factor equal to the number of separate paths observed
Transmission rates must be decreased by a factor equal to the number of separate paths observed
No significant changes will occur if the signals are transmitted using FM
questions.answer: Error rates are likely to increase

questions.label: T3A11
questions.text: Which part of the atmosphere enables the propagation of radio signals around the world?

questions.label: T3A12
questions.text: How might fog and light rain affect radio range on the 10 meter and 6 meter bands?
distractors: Fog and rain absorb these wavelength bands
Fog and rain will deflect these signals
Fog and rain will increase radio range
questions.answer: Fog and light rain will have little effect on these bands

questions.label: T3A13
questions.text: What weather condition would decrease range at microwave frequencies?

subTopics.label: T3B
subTopics.description: Radio and electromagnetic wave properties: the electromagnetic spectrum; wavelength vs frequency; nature and velocity of electromagnetic waves; definition of UHF, VHF, HF bands; calculating wavelength

questions.label: T3B01
questions.text: What is the name for the distance a radio wave travels during one complete cycle?

questions.label: T3B02
questions.text: What property of a radio wave is used to describe its polarization?
distractors: The orientation of the magnetic field
The ratio of the energy in the magnetic field to the energy in the electric field
The ratio of the velocity to the wavelength
questions.answer: The orientation of the electric field

questions.label: T3B03
questions.text: What are the two components of a radio wave?

questions.label: T3B04
questions.text: How fast does a radio wave travel through free space?
distractors: Its speed is inversely proportional to its wavelength
Its speed increases as the frequency increases

questions.label: T3B05
questions.text: How does the wavelength of a radio wave relate to its frequency?
distractors: The wavelength gets longer as the frequency increases
There is no relationship between wavelength and frequency
The wavelength depends on the bandwidth of the signal
questions.answer: The wavelength gets shorter as the frequency increases

questions.label: T3B06
questions.text: What is the formula for converting frequency to approximate wavelength in meters?
distractors: Wavelength in meters equals frequency in hertz multiplied by 300
Wavelength in meters equals frequency in hertz divided by 300
Wavelength in meters equals frequency in megahertz divided by 300
questions.answer: Wavelength in meters equals 300 divided by frequency in megahertz

questions.label: T3B07
questions.text: What property of radio waves is often used to identify the different frequency bands?
distractors: The time it takes for waves to travel one mile
The voltage standing wave ratio of waves

questions.label: T3B08
questions.text: What are the frequency limits of the VHF spectrum?

questions.label: T3B09
questions.text: What are the frequency limits of the UHF spectrum?

questions.label: T3B10
questions.text: What frequency range is referred to as HF?

questions.label: T3B11
questions.text: What is the approximate velocity of a radio wave as it travels through free space?

subTopics.label: T3C
subTopics.description: Propagation modes: line of sight; sporadic E; meteor and auroral scatter and reflections; tropospheric ducting; F layer skip; radio horizon

questions.label: T3C01
questions.text: Why are direct (not via a repeater) UHF signals rarely heard from stations outside your local coverage area?
distractors: They are too weak to go very far
FCC regulations prohibit them from going more than 50 miles
UHF signals are absorbed by the ionospheric D layer
questions.answer: UHF signals are usually not reflected by the ionosphere

questions.label: T3C02
questions.text: Which of the following is an advantage of HF vs VHF and higher frequencies?
distractors: There is less atmospheric interference (static) on HF
questions.answer: Long distance ionospheric propagation is far more common on HF

questions.label: T3C03
questions.text: What is a characteristic of VHF signals received via auroral reflection?
distractors: Signals from distances of 10,000 or more miles are common
These types of signals occur only during winter nighttime hours
These types of signals are generally strongest when your antenna is aimed west
questions.answer: The signals exhibit rapid fluctuations of strength and often sound distorted

questions.label: T3C04
questions.text: Which of the following propagation types is most commonly associated with occasional strong over-the-horizon signals on the 10, 6, and 2 meter bands?

questions.label: T3C05
questions.text: Which of the following effects might cause radio signals to be heard despite obstructions between the transmitting and receiving stations?

questions.label: T3C06
questions.text: What mode is responsible for allowing over-the-horizon VHF and UHF communications to ranges of approximately 300 miles on a regular basis?

questions.label: T3C07
questions.text: What band is best suited for communicating via meteor scatter?

questions.label: T3C08
questions.text: What causes tropospheric ducting?
distractors: Discharges of lightning during electrical storms

questions.label: T3C09
questions.text: What is generally the best time for long-distance 10 meter band propagation via the F layer?
distractors: From shortly after sunset to dawn during periods of high sunspot activity
From dawn to shortly after sunset during periods of low sunspot activity
From shortly after sunset to dawn during periods of low sunspot activity
questions.answer: From dawn to shortly after sunset during periods of high sunspot activity

questions.label: T3C10
questions.text: Which of the following bands may provide long distance communications during the peak of the sunspot cycle?
distractors: All of these choices are correct

questions.label: T3C11
questions.text: Why do VHF and UHF radio signals usually travel somewhat farther than the visual line of sight distance between two stations?
distractors: Radio signals move somewhat faster than the speed of light
Radio waves are not blocked by dust particles
Radio waves are blocked by dust particles
questions.answer: The Earth seems less curved to radio waves than to light

SubElements.label: T4
SubElements.description: Amateur radio practices and station set-up

subTopics.label: T4A
subTopics.description: Station setup: connecting microphones; reducing unwanted emissions; power source; connecting a computer; RF grounding; connecting digital equipment; connecting an SWR meter

questions.label: T4A01
questions.text: What must be considered to determine the minimum current capacity needed for a transceiver power supply?
distractors: Efficiency of the transmitter at full power output
Power supply regulation and heat dissipation
questions.answer: All of these choices are correct

questions.label: T4A02
questions.text: How might a computer be used as part of an amateur radio station?
distractors: For logging contacts and contact information
For generating and decoding digital signals
questions.answer: All of these choices are correct

questions.label: T4A03
questions.text: Why should wiring between the power source and radio be heavy-gauge wire and kept as short as possible?
distractors: To provide a good counterpoise for the antenna
All of these choices are correct
questions.answer: To avoid voltage falling below that needed for proper operation

questions.label: T4A04
questions.text: Which computer sound card port is connected to a transceiver’s headphone or speaker output for operating digital modes?

questions.label: T4A05
questions.text: What is the proper location for an external SWR meter?
distractors: In series with the station's ground
In parallel with the push-to-talk line and the antenna
In series with the power supply cable, as close as possible to the radio
questions.answer: In series with the feed line, between the transmitter and antenna

questions.label: T4A06
questions.text: Which of the following connections might be used between a voice transceiver and a computer for digital operation?
distractors: Receive and transmit mode, status, and location
NMEA GPS location and DC power
questions.answer: Receive audio, transmit audio, and push-to-talk (PTT)

questions.label: T4A07
questions.text: How is a computer’s sound card used when conducting digital communications?
distractors: The sound card communicates between the computer CPU and the video display
The sound card records the audio frequency for video display
All of these choices are correct
questions.answer: The sound card provides audio to the radio's microphone input and converts received audio to digital form

questions.label: T4A08
questions.text: Which of the following conductors provides the lowest impedance to RF signals?

questions.label: T4A09
questions.text: Which of the following could you use to cure distorted audio caused by RF current on the shield of a microphone cable?

questions.label: T4A10
questions.text: What is the source of a high-pitched whine that varies with engine speed in a mobile transceiver’s receive audio?

questions.label: T4A11
questions.text: Where should the negative return connection of a mobile transceiver's power cable be connected?
distractors: To any metal part of the vehicle
questions.answer: At the battery or engine block ground strap

subTopics.label: T4B
subTopics.description: Operating controls: tuning; use of filters; squelch function; AGC; transceiver operation; memory channels

questions.label: T4B01
questions.text: What may happen if a transmitter is operated with the microphone gain set too high?
distractors: The output power might be too high
questions.answer: The output signal might become distorted

questions.label: T4B02
questions.text: Which of the following can be used to enter the operating frequency on a modern transceiver?
distractors: All of these choices are correct

questions.label: T4B03
questions.text: What is the purpose of the squelch control on a transceiver?
distractors: To set the highest level of volume desired
To set the transmitter power level
To adjust the automatic gain control
questions.answer: To mute receiver output noise when no signal is being received

questions.label: T4B04
questions.text: What is a way to enable quick access to a favorite frequency on your transceiver?
distractors: Use the scan mode to select the desired frequency
questions.answer: Store the frequency in a memory channel

questions.label: T4B05
questions.text: Which of the following would reduce ignition interference to a receiver?

questions.label: T4B06
questions.text: Which of the following controls could be used if the voice pitch of a single-sideband signal seems too high or low?

questions.label: T4B07
questions.text: What does the term “RIT” mean?

questions.label: T4B08
questions.text: What is the advantage of having multiple receive bandwidth choices on a multimode transceiver?
distractors: Permits monitoring several modes at once
Increases the number of frequencies that can be stored in memory
Increases the amount of offset between receive and transmit frequencies
questions.answer: Permits noise or interference reduction by selecting a bandwidth matching the mode

questions.label: T4B09
questions.text: Which of the following is an appropriate receive filter bandwidth for minimizing noise and interference for SSB reception?

questions.label: T4B10
questions.text: Which of the following is an appropriate receive filter bandwidth for minimizing noise and interference for CW reception?

questions.label: T4B11
questions.text: What is the function of automatic gain control, or AGC?
distractors: To protect an antenna from lightning
To eliminate RF on the station cabling
An asymmetric goniometer control used for antenna matching
questions.answer: To keep received audio relatively constant

questions.label: T4B12
questions.text: Which of the following could be used to remove power line noise or ignition noise?
distractors: All of these choices are correct

questions.label: T4B13
questions.text: Which of the following is a use for the scanning function of an FM transceiver?
distractors: To prevent interference to nearby repeaters
To check for messages left on a digital bulletin board
questions.answer: To scan through a range of frequencies to check for activity

Current (I) equals voltage (E) added to resistance (R)

distractors: Voltage (E) equals current (I) divided by resistance (R)
Voltage (E) equals current (I) added to resistance (R)
questions.answer: Voltage (E) equals current (I) multiplied by resistance (R)

distractors: Resistance (R) equals voltage (E) multiplied by current (I)
Resistance (R) equals voltage (E) added to current (I)
